That when she passes, each one she passes goes “ah!”

Clever double meaning; People say “ah” when they are scared, but also when they want to express pleasure. So in this case, the girl from impanema is sneaking up on people (probably from behind) and startling them (grabbing their shoulders and/or yelling “boo)”. Victims experience a sense of fear, but, in realizing the beauty of the delinquent, are quickly overcome with a warm and gentle delight. Ah!
Tall and tan and young and lovely
Stan sing about Heloísa Eneida Paes Pinto Mendes Pinheiro, who is now a model, which he saw go get cigarettes for her mother.

Oh, but he watches her so sadly
 How can he tell her he loves her?
 Yes, he would give his heart gladly
 But each day when she walks to the sea
 She looks straight ahead not at he

This is the B section of the song, which is very noticable due to the chords being used and the lyrics.

Notice how in the verses the person singing is looking at a woman walking on the beach of Ipanema. However in this bridge section the lyrics become more reflexive and the singer starts comtemplating.

The chords being used in this section are strange to analyze when applying western music theory. This is very typically bossa nova, which makes is very distinguishable from other music styles.

Translated from Portuguese:

Look what a beautiful thing, more full of grace
She is a girl who comes and who goes
On a sweet swing on the way to the sea
Golden body girl of the Ipanema sun
Your swing is more than a poem
It is the most beautiful thing I have ever seen.

And when she passes he smiles
 But she doesn’t see

The girl from Ipanema, although being quite a lovely girl, has no idea that the writers of the song admire her gorgeous appearance each day.

Composer Antônio Carlos Jobim and poet Vinícius de Moraes were hanging out in Rio de Janeiro in the early 60’s when they first laid eyes on Heloísa Eneida Menezes Paes Pinto Pinheiro (also known as Helô). Helô was probably one of the most beautiful women in all of Brazil, and did not care for any of the men (especially older ones) that stared at her all day while she was on the beach.

Having this as the last line in the single version really hammers home the tone of somber lonesomeness despite being in paradise. Although the girl is the most beautiful thing the songwriter has ever seen, he can’t do anything about it. He shows that even when we are at the beautiful beaches of Rio, we are still affected by loneliness.

Translated from Portuguese:

Oh, why am I so alone?
Oh, why is everything so sad?
Ah, the beauty that exists
The beauty that is not just mine
That also goes alone

If only she knew
That when she passes
The smiling world is filled with grace
And it is more beautiful because of love
Moça do corpo dourado do sol de Ipanema

Ipanema is well known as a beautiful beach in the southern zone of Rio de Janeiro, Brazil. It’s known to be a beautiful, elegant beach as a very popular part of the neighborhood. Interestingly enough, it is ironic how the world “Ipanema” originally derives from the indigenous Tupi language and means “stinky lake”.
The girl from Ipanema goes walking

The girl that Jobim and Gilberto refer to is Heloísa Eneida Menezes Paes Pinto Pinheiro (also known as Helô), a native from Rio de Janeiro.

The fame she received from the song began her career as a model, to which she continues to be recognized for her beauty.

http://www.sfgate.com/travel/article/Girl-from-Ipanema-ages-gracefully-Still-tall-2537969.php

Since the identity of the “girl from Ipanema” is very vague, when the song was first released, there was widespread speculation as to who she was and inspired a line-up of “pretenders” who claimed to be the inspiration of the song. In 1965, the lyricist, Vinícius de Moraes, held a press conference to set the record straight.

When she walks she’s like a samba that
 Swings so cool and sways so gently

This lyric is suggestive of what the bossa nova artists were doing to Brazilian music. Samba is anything but gentle and cool. It does not sway or swing. It is energetic and powerful. The bossa nova artists moved away from the frenetic style of samba to a toned-down, minimalistic music for the more refined middle and upper classes. Thus, this description of the girl from Ipanema is a reflection of the changes that the bossa nova artists made to Brazilian music and culture.
